question.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the transport of gases by blood?

options.text: The oxygen dissociation curve is sigmoid and shifts to the right at high pCO<sub>2</sub>, and low pH.
Every 100 ml of oxygenated blood can deliver around 5 ml of O<sub>2</sub> to the tissues under normal physiological conditions.
The major factor affecting the formation of carbamino-hemoglobin is low H<sup>+</sup> concentration.
Approximately 70% of carbon dioxide is carried as bicarbonates.

solution.text: CO<sub>2</sub> is carried by hemoglobin as carbamino-hemoglobin (about 20-25 percent). This binding is related to the partial pressure of CO<sub>2</sub>. pO<sub>2</sub> is a major factor that could affect this binding. When pCO<sub>2</sub> is high and pO<sub>2</sub> is low as in the tissues, more binding of carbon dioxide occurs whereas, when the pCO<sub>2</sub> is low and pO<sub>2</sub> is high as in the alveoli, dissociation takes place.
